question: Question_02_(b)
sols:
We use the method of washers.

For any \emph{x} in \emph{(-1,2)}, the larger and smaller radii \emph{R}
and \emph{r} of the washer is given by

\[R(x) = 5-(x+1) = 4-x \,\]

\[r(x) = 5-(4-(x-1)^2) = 1+(x-1)^2 \,\] (The simplifications given above
are not really necessary)

Notice that the larger radius \emph{R} is given by the distance from the
axis of revolution \emph{y=5} to the lower curve, because it is further
away.

Therefore, the area of the washer is

\[A(x) = (R^2 - r^2)\pi = \left[(4-x)^2 - \left(1+(x-1)^2\right)^2\right]\pi\]

Now we can write down the integral that represents the volume of the
solid of revolution:

\begin{align*}
V &= \int_{-1}^2 A(x) dx \\
&= \pi \left[\int_{-1}^2 (4-x)^2 - \left(1+(x-1)^2\right)^2 dx \right]\\
\end{align*}

\textbf{According to the question statement, we may stop here.}

\emph{If you are interested to find the value of the integral, read on.}

To solve this integral, we split it in two parts and write

\[V =  \pi \left[ \int_{-1}^2 (4-x)^2 dx - \int_{-1}^2 \left(1+(x-1)^2\right)^2 dx \right]\]

We refrain from expanding the brackets but make a change of variables
\emph{u=4-x, du=-dx} and \emph{v=x-1, dv=dx} for the first and second
integral respectively. Not forgetting to update the integration limits,
we arrive at

\begin{align*}
V &= \pi \left[\int_{-1}^2 (4-x)^2 dx - \int_{-1}^2 \left(1+(x-1)^2\right)^2 dx \right]\\
&= \pi \left[\int_5^2 u^2 (-du) - \int_{-2}^1 \left(1+v^2\right)^2 dv \right]\\
&= \pi \left[\int_2^5 u^2 du - \int_{-2}^1 \left(1+2v^2+v^4\right) dv \right]\\
&= \pi \left( \left[u^3/3\right]^5_2 - \left[v+2v^3/3+v^5/5\right]_{-2}^1 \right)\\
&= \pi \left( (125-8)/3 -\left[3+2(1+8)/3+(1+32)/5\right] \right)\\
&= \pi \left( 39 - 3 - 6 - 6 - 3/5 \right)\\
&= \pi \left( 24 - 3/5 \right) = 117\pi / 5\\
\end{align*}
hints:
Use the method of washers (cross-sections).

Look at the sketch at part a), the cross-sections are formed by
intersecting the region \emph{R} by a straight line \emph{x=c} where
\emph{-1\textless{}c\textless{}2}, and then rotating the line segment
about the axis \emph{y=5}. The result should look like a washer.

To find the volume of revolution, find the area of this washer as a
function of \emph{x} and then integrate from the left to right endpoint
of the region.
